section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with feelings movements, and introduce vocabulary (disappointed, blue).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book. Ask, What different feelings can people have?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help or information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.
Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children create Feeling Plates out of paper plates and art supplies.
Invite children to use their Feeling Plates to indicate what they’re feeling.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What feelings do some of your favorite characters show?
Act out one of the feelings you saw in the The Way I Feel.
Look around. How many feelings can you see on people’s faces?
Can you write a story about a happy day?
Make a colorful drawing to show how you feel right now.
The word blue starts with the letter B. Can you find a letter B in the classroom?
Use blocks to make a face with a big smile. How many feelings can you show with blocks?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder identify feelings in others and introduce vocabulary (shout, feelings).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Way I Feel.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help and information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Sentence Structure: Use single words or phrases as appropriate (Multilingual Learners).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify feelings in others.
Invite children to talk about how they express their feelings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you tell what feelings your favorite characters are showing?
Pretend to be a character in The Way I Feel.
Which feeling do you think you’ve had the most often?
Write or draw a picture about the feeling you like best.
Create three characters that show different feelings.
The word feelings starts with the letter F. What sound does the letter F make?
Use blocks to show how many feelings you learned about today.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill, talk about feelings, and introduce vocabulary (mighty, suddenly).
Begin Story Time by revisiting The Way I Feel and asking, What makes you feel happy or proud?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help and information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Sentence Structure: Use single words or phrases as appropriate (Multilingual Learners).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.
different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children look at pictures and say if a happy or sad feeling is shown.
Invite children to describe when they felt the same emotions they saw in the pictures.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find stories with characters who are happy.
Show how you would try to help someone who’s having a hard time with their feelings.
Can you find three smiling children in your class? Count them.
Draw a picture to show your friend you are happy.
Use molding clay to make a heart. Share it with a friend.
The word mighty starts with the letter M. What sound does the letter M make?
What other materials can you use to make a heart?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Way I Feel by Janan Cain. Copyright © 2000 by Janan Cain. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Parenting Press, Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: If You’re Happy and You Know It

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about all of the different feelings the children have learned about, play a game of “Simon Says,” and introduce vocabulary words (scared, surprised).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts If You’re Happy and You Know It and The Way I Feel.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purpose and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help and information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Sentence Structure: Use single words or phrases as appropriate (Multilingual Learners).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children look at picture cards and identify the feeling by the action the person in the picture is doing.
Invite children to repeat the action they see in the picture.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Sing the words to the song “If You’re Happy and You Know It.”
Pretend you are surprised. What action would you show?
How many actions can you use to show that you are happy?
Write about what you like to do when you’re happy.
Draw a line down the center of a piece of paper. Draw yourself happy on one side and sad on the other.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word surprised? Can you make that sound?
Can you build something very silly out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Way I Feel by Janan Cain. Copyright © 2000 by Janan Cain. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Parenting Press, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have a Feelings Parade, play an letter game, and introduce vocabulary (frustrated, jealous).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book. Ask, How can you feel better when you are sad?
Read and retell interactively for emotional development.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Ask and answer questions to seek help and information; Ask and answer questions about a text.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand words similar in meaning.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Sentence Structure: Use single words or phrases as appropriate (Multilingual Learners).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Build and maintain relationships with peers and trusted adults over time.
Identify emotions in others.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure
Mind Builders: Social Development; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What can we learn from our feelings?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What stories have you read that show how children talk about their feelings?
Imagine that you have a dog that shows you when he’s happy. What does the dog do?
Find out how many of your classmates have the same favorite feeling as you.
Draw a feeling that you do not like.
Draw a big heart and add things you love inside of it.
The word jealous starts with the /j/ sound. Can you think of any words that start with the letter J?
Create a scary scene. What can you change to make it less scary?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Way I Feel by Janan Cain. Copyright © 2000 by Janan Cain. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Parenting Press, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways of knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers/adults.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways of knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than he or she uses.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways of knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
a variety of art materials for sensory experience and exploration.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways of knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways of knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than he or she uses.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use single words and simple phrases to communicate meaning in social situations.
Use effective verbal and nonverbal communication skills to build relationships with teachers and adults.
Demonstrate understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from their own.
